commitResults.messageTitle: Added greet() and bye() functions to Clam.java
Added scanner to read user input and echo accordingly
created new Task class, introduced marking functionality

commitResults.messageBody:
Add Text UI Testing via input/output redirection technique to
semi-automate the testing of Clam.

Error handling is currently hard-coded.

Proper error handling will make the code more structured and easier to
update when more features are added and more possible errors arise.

Error handling lets us inform the user what went wrong with their
inputs and helps them to figure out how to use the app properly.

We can streamline error handling using Exceptions, which allows us to
catch exceptions that occur at any point throughout the code.

Clam currently does not allow users to delete items in their task list.

Being able to delete items allows users to correct mistakes or remove
items that they didn't intend to add.

App data does not persist across instances.

Storing user data on their device allows them to keep track of
their tasks even if they have to close the app (e.g. to shut down
their device).

Let's use Scanner and FileWriter to read and write to a text file,
storing the information of each task in a delimited format.

Using a text file to store data is simple and human editable,
which makes it easy to evolve and troubleshoot.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add proper date/time format for data storage
commitResults.messageBody:
Duke currently accepts any string as the input for dates in Deadline
and Event tasks, regardless of whether the string represents a date
in any way.

Change the type that we store it in from String to LocalDate, using
the relevant parsing and printing methods to ensure standardised
storage of info in the text file.

This change of type allows us to make use of the date/time of tasks
in meaningful ways in the future, for example, if we want to view the
tasks in order of due soonest to latest.

commitResults.messageTitle: Organise the codebase using more OOP and packages
commitResults.messageBody:
The codebase is currently disorganised, with most of the logic being
thrown into the main Clam.java file.

Organising the code based on OOP principles helps to compartmentalise
logic, creating a codebase that is easier to expand and evolve. Using
packages also helps us to keep files organised as well.

The enum variables have also been replaced with the Command class and
its respective subclasses, each corresponding to a possible command in
the program. Using an abstract Command class allows to generalise our
execution and allow polymorphism to ensure that the correct logic gets
run for each specific command.

This is done to ensure that our codebase is expandable as we add more
features and more lines of code.

There is currently no automation of tasks for this project.

Being able to automate builds and tasks allows us to streamline the
development process and ensure that we do not miss out on anything when
we make new commits and pushes.

We add gradle support to our codebase.

There is currently no automated testing for the program.

Automated testing will make checking the functionality of our code more
efficient as we continue to develop it and add new features.

Add JUnit test cases to run using Gradle.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add jar file & minor bug fix
commitResults.messageBody:
Created a JAR file for the program (linked in the github repo).

Also made a minor bug fix where mark/unmark commands did not immediately
save to file, and those changes would be discarded unless another
command was run afterwards before the program was shut down.

The codebase currently does not contain much documentation of any form.

JavaDoc helps to provide information about how classes and methods in
this program work at a quick glance, as well as integrates seamlessly
with most IDEs' JavaDoc integration.

commitResults.messageTitle: Tweak the code to comply with a coding standard
commitResults.messageBody:
The codebase is currently not fully standardised to a coding standard.

We use IntelliJ's code style configurations to help us maintain a
coding standard across the entire codebase.

There is currently no way of searching or filtering tasks by name.

Being able to find tasks by searching will be useful for all users and
essential for power users who will have many tasks.

Let's add a find command that searches through all tasks in the task
list, and returns every task that contains the input string using regex.

This find command is case-sensitive. It is currently not of a high
priority to configure the find command to be case-insensitive, as the
necessity of it is minimal.

The current UI is text-based and in the terminal/command line.

Most users are not going to be familiar with terminals and CLI based
apps, but rather graphical user interfaces (GUIs).

Let's add a GUI using JavaFX, and reroute the user input into this new
GUI's display.

There are currently no assertions in the code.

Assertions help us to verify that certain invariants are met throughout
our code.

Let's add assertions at points in our code where certain conditions
should be always true, but is not checked or guaranteed to be the case,
where these conditions are vital for the program's functionality.

commitResults.messageTitle: Improve code quality of the codebase
commitResults.messageBody:
The codebase has not been checked for code quality issues.

Ensuring a certain level of code quality is essential for readability,
which is especially important when maintaining a repo that other people
will be able to view, modify and update.

Let's review all existing code files and ensure that they follow the
code quality standards outlined in CS2103T's syllabus.
Add Assertions
Improve code quality of the codebase

There is currently no guide or help manual for users.

New users may not know what commands are available or what they do,
so having a help manual allows them to learn what these commands are to
be able to use Clam fully.

Let's add a detailed help message for every command available in Clam,
and have the help command itself print out all possible commands for
the user's reference. Additionally, if the program starts up and detects
that the task list is empty, it will assume that the user might be new
and show an additional message letting them know about the help command.

commitResults.messageTitle: Improve the GUI using GitHub CoPilot
commitResults.messageBody:
The GUI looks very basic.

A better GUI makes the program more visually appealing and betters the
user experience.

Let's use GitHub CoPilot to automate code changes in the realm of GUI
and JavaFX, to make the GUI look better and more polished overall.

The Clam program does not yet have a user guide.

A user guide will help new users learn how to use the program
effectively.

Let's add a README.md file with information what Clam is and how to use
its features.
